Tastes like a Budweiser but with more malty corn flavor, overly fizzy on the palate.  Crisp and drinkable, but no different than a cheap American macro.  Overall: a label that makes macro drinkers feel sophisticated (and there is nothing wrong with macros or macro drinkers, just macro drinkers who think they are sophisticated fro drinking a Peroni or a Stella)
Run of the mill lager with nothing special going on. The aftertaste has a fresh biterness though, and it goes well with a warm summerday with pizza and folklore.

Bottle at Village Pub. Pourd clear amber color with an average frothy white head that diminished slowly with good lacing. Medium sweet grainy aroma. Light to medium body with soft carbonation. Medium sweet flavor with a medium sweet finish of short duration.

Bottle.  Pours a pale yellow with a thin white head that quickly disappeared.  Sweet, grainy (corn) aroma with some malt detected as well.  Flavor is just as bad with some grassy hops at the finish.  Thin mouthfeel.  This stuff is crap.

pale, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, bitter, likable European style beer.  Has a softer taste than a German pilsner.  Goes well with spicy Italian food.

4oz Taster - Hop Scotch Spring Festival - Seattle, WA 

Aroma – Light pale lager aroma.  Very light hops. Just a plain smelling beer.

Appearance – Light golden color, clear with a nice head. 

Flavor – A decent flavor light malt with a very little to no hops in the flavor. 
 
Palate – Beer Mouthfeel, good texture with a dry finish. 

Overall – A easy to drink beer nothing special this was a lager and had lager qualities.  Bland beer.
Bottle: Skunky, sour taste and smell. However easy to drink. I actually like it when eating pizza. Must be the italian thing.
AWFUL.  Bitter, sour, funky, and lots of bubbles.  No reason to drink this....EVER.
Peroni looks almost clear. Very very pale white/yellow. Smells very tarty/sour. Taste is also tarty and sour. Horrible. Almost like a wine or champane.
Pours gold. Kind of skunky, maybe malt and grassy hops in the nose. Flavor is weak. Drinkable? yes. Not worth the price.

Pours a clear yellow with a thin, fizzy head that vanishes quickly.  Aroma is skunky, no matter how fresh the beer.  Flavor is very negligible, with maybe just a hint of sweet grain.  Mouthfeel is nice and crisp, but that’s not really enough to recommend this beer.

Bottled. A clear yellow beer with a medium sized and fast disappearing white head. The aroma is simple, corny, lightly hoppy. The flavour is sweet, again corny and industrial; Quite light body, lively/fizzy carbonation, short finish with light bitterness. Not the worst Italian supermarket lager, but almost useless.
Bottle ... once again, a mainstream italian beer doesn´t deliver. not much taste, very little after taste.
garbage. worse than your standard American garbage lagers. wouldn’t drink again, ever.

Roma, roma va fan culo
Corpo di testa, centraliziacione
milan, milan toa matre es estronza

Tastes like san pelligrino with alcohol.  Stay away from this one.  I am convinced that Italy has no taste in beer if this is their most popluar.  The fact that they are still in business shows how gracious America is in helping the helpless.
Compared to some of the options you can get in Vegas.  This was ok.  It took at couple of sips to get used to the taste, because it was sort of skunky.

Certainly a better option than your typical American Lager. Pours a light golden color with a small white head. The head tapers off quickly and there’s not much lace to speak of. Pretty good hoppy balanced flavor to it and was quite smooth. Nice mouthfeel and the finish was fairly clean, although a hint of a "skunky" taste. Compared to a Bud, Michelob, Miller, etc this is much more flavorful and smooth, but compared to other beers in general this is nothing special. As expected it went pretty well with the Italian dish I was having. Although, if I were eating Italian food I’d take an Italian red wine over this any day
Nothing special from this Italian pilsner style lager.  Thin flavor and a bit watery.  Has hints of a macrobrew and flavors of cereal and corn.
Draught with thin white head. Smooth but seems a bit weak. Very drinkable as a draught.

Okay beer.  About as good as Moretti.  Again, any beer that you can buy from a vending machine is okay in my book.  Still, not true flavors to speak of.  Not the best Pils, but still better than most American pilsners.
Bottle. Gold, thin white head, gentle condition. Slight fruitiness in the nose, faintly caramel sweet in the mouth and short and dry in the finish.
Botella. Es una mala cerveza, de un pais que no tiene una gran tradiccion cervecera  y ni siquiera un gran consumo

Draft @ Junior’s in Winooski, VT - Poured a golden amber in color with a small white head that faded quickly.  Aroma was a bit skunky with sweet hints of corn and other fermentation adjuncts.  Flavor was much of the typical "mega" lager... pretty unremarkable.  No trace of the bitterness from the commercial description.  Might was well be drinking "Bud"...
I just had the opportunity have this on draft and I really liked it. Very drinkable.

Just what one mught expect from a SABMiller beer.
SAme ole’ same ole"
can’t think of much to say that isn’t libellous - then again if it’s true I guess it can’t be libellous after all. nothing to commend this at all. draught in Milan area.
12 0z. bottle, this starts off as a typical euro maco and finishes the same as well, not bad and is refreshing but not much different than what is produced here in the states
Bottle 0.3 l. Very pale yellow, moderate whitish head. Nose is sweet, grassy and slightlty malty. Flavor is mildly malty with fresh grassy and a bit buttery hoppiness. Quite thin, but not that bad.

Had on tap in Venice, Italy with a big ass calzone.  Goes down smooth with very little bite and a slight after-taste.  A good beer to have after a day of walking the streets of any city and needing something to refresh.  Also, goes great with veal parmesan!
from bottle poured clear golden color with a fiar amount of head.  Good flavor with a quick finish.
Hmmm Peroni. Non è che la sono andata a cercare, ma "mi è capitata fra capo e collo". Non saprei scrivere granché su questa delizia sopraffina se non che ovviamente ve la consiglio.
Nov. 2006 - Vibrant yellow, fuzzy head. Aroma of corn. Flavor of sweet corn as well. Weak, too. Not overly skunky, a little grassy. This isn’t really worth further thought. Yuck
Typical pale lager, light body, light flavor, not much to really talk about.
ok...cuts kind of crisp, gassy and grassy..a little more bitter then other pale lagers.
Golden pour with white head.  Aroma of straw and corn.  Taste of alcohol and straw.  Smooth bitter finish.
From the bottle at Mayor West’s. Slightly skunky with hints of grass. Overly carbonated and bland flavor. Easy to drink but not something to stock the fridge with.
Ahh you sure can tell the main ingredient is WATER!!! bland yellow , a little head, not much nose maybe some corn. drinkable but boring
To me, the corn certainly does not mix well with the hops, producing a bitter mess within the mouth. Not one that is completely intolerable but I won’t go picking it out in a store.
Bottle. This beer is the exact opposite of everything you expect something from Italy to be. I’m not so sure this wasnt really made in Milwalkee. Do Italians really drink this stuff?
Relatively clean and innocuous. Vacuous. Too carbonated but mouthfeel has some softness. I’ve had worse.

pours extremely pale yellow,  probably the lightest ive ever seen in a beer,  little white head.  Wheat,  yeast,  skunk for aroma and flavor.  Finishes easy enough,  with little carbonation and a sunky aftertaste.  Meh.

From a 12 ounce bottle sampled from a friend at my sister’s wedding. Poured a pale yellow with a very small head that disappeared quickly. Aromas of hops, yeast, and malt helped make this beer very skunky. There was a good amount of carbonation however. Tasted very bitter with a somewhat foul aftertaste. It was a good thirst-quencher after a few hours of dancing, but I would definitely not seek this one out again.

Sharp metallic Hallertau or corn(?)--expected from the green-bottled non-beer producing nations of Europe...light bread malt...tawny pale gold translucent body; a white frothy head that dissipates to a thin tracing...body is moderately effervescent.... smooth and minimal texture--starts and finishes with nondescription... clear and crisp--a bit watered to the point of refreshingness... trouble is naming a taste without a flavor--a bit of wood? "palate cleansing" is the compliment the Urquell/Peroni/Tyskie sampler’s guide ascribed to this lager, and the attribute sticks... as for the taste, this is beer best served in pairings, either with Italian dishes, cheeses, or five or six other Peronis, I believe...

From 12-oz bottle, sampled at friend’s New Year’s party. Pours a clear golden pale brew with a fast dissolving white head that leaves behind a thin white ring. Aroma of light bready malt, some corn malt, grassy hops and some vegetable. Taste is light bodied, well-carbonated with some light bread and citrus hop flavors. Finish is slightly bitter and grainy with a light citrus hop aftertaste. A few hours in the sun with this brew and it would make an instant skonk.
medium body, thin feel, flat, bitter, an Italian average beer, would have given it a better overall rating but not worth the money.

Bottle: Pours an average, fizzy head that provides some light lacing onto a yellow body.  There is an average aroma of malt, hops, and yeast, all of which are largely stock and nondescript.  My o’l nose may’ve even detected a bit of vinegar to the aroma.  The body is light, slick, and the carbonation is nearly non-existent with an astringent finish.  The beer is moderately bitter in flavor, and again at tasting, I detect some vinegar.  It’s a basic beer which is like a lot of big mass-produced beers...Fun if you’re at an Italian restaurant, but you can certainly do better for cheaper.

Poured a glass last night and as soon as my wife came into the room she stated that something smelt aweful.  I told her to check the fridge due to large amount of leftovers.  As soon as she came over to me she determined it was the beer.  Not a bad refreshing taste, but the smell of skunk is terrible.

Why is this a beer when it tastes like champagne? Jokes aside, a sweet bubbly lager that complements Thai food rather well, cleansing the palate after each bite and complementing spicy curries. Typical skunky lager aroma.

Pours an average shade of transparent golden, thin white head. Aroma is basic "beer" scent. Taste is much the same as almost any American macro lager, only slightly sweeter and slightly crisper. Moderate carbonation. I’ll skip to the chase...if you’re looking to try something new and there arent any other choices, go for it. If you want something good, look harder. This brew isn’t terrible, just boring and average. Also, costs more  than your average American macro, so why bother unless you just want to add one more to your rating?
Almost as thirst quinching as water!  Extremely pale.  Corn like taste.  Pale lager!
Sampled at wifes Xmas party (only thing that looked remotely good). Light yellow, straw color with a thin white head. Sweet corn aroma. Sweet grain taste, but light easy drink. Nothing special.

Appearance: transparent straw color. Little to medium head, white with some persistent.
Aroma: corn mainly. Citric, herby and grassy smells from hops (extract).
Taste: (some insipid) corn adds sweetness. Some citric fruitiness with reminiscences of lemon and grapefruits. Poor hoppy some herby. Mineralized and metallic finish.
Palate: light body and watery texture. Medium carbonation.
On tap in a Peroni tall glass.  Pours a very pale yellow color with a small white head.  Scents of yeast and malt.  Very uneventful palate.  Boring and bland with no bitterness or hops.  Yuk

bottle - Meh.  It’s another pale lager.  Yes, it’s clear and yellow with a white head.  It smells like grainy malt.  It has the usual sweet malt flavor and actually manages some light hops as many light European lagers do.  It’s thin and bland, but it’s inoffensive.  It could be worse and might actually be refreshing at times.
Not a horrible beer but not much to it basically a heniken with a different label.
After reading some of these other reviews I feel slightly ashamed that I didnt think this beer was that bad.
Unfortunetly this was my best tap option where i was.  Weak, but at least it was on special.  Basically along the lines of bud light, but with a funky smell.  Fizzy, only drink it if you have to.

What a waste of time. There was no reason to make this. It is a weak and utterly forgettable carbonated beverage. It is a marketing effort, a label. Listen Italy, nobody will blame you for sticking to wine. You do it well and it’s what everyone expects. We won’t count it against you if you don’t make beer. Promise. The Jamaican bobsled team is an amusing novelty, but nobody will miss them when they disband. Come one now, you’ve had your fun.

Pours a pretty pale golden color with a two finger spattered froth that dies off quickly. No lacework at all. Aromas of skunked grains. Light to medium nectar with ample residual effers. Tastes like a macro import  beer. Nothing offensive, just bland and meaningless.
Boring. The only thing not boring was the skunk and the price. I should have saved the extra buck and had a Coors Lite. Stay away.
Bottle. Skunky malt nose, straw and corn. Pale yellow, short live white head. Severe lack of flavor, a touch of faint sourness in the finish. Rough palate.

66 cL bottle. Pours golden clear yellow with a lacing white head. Minor malty dry aroma with a slight note of bitterhops. Soft mouthfeel. Flavour is soft malty with almost no bitterness in the finish. Somewhat too simple, yet I assume it to work as intended on a warm Summers day - although I have a better understanding of why the Italians drink wine more than beer.
12 ounce bottle available at Total Wine Ft Lauderdale, FL at $1.49 Average.
Bottle:  Had in Italy.  Clear golden colour.  Lighter body and a bit of a bitter taste.
[Bottle from Campo del Forte.] Mainstream italian fluid, even not worse to swallow in the heat, because the vino rosso was better. Brought it to Denmark, where it went easier down.

Bottle-Clear golden color; some hop aroma. Pretty standard lagar, nothing to get too excited about. Easy drinking, inoffensive. Best option @ Virginia Beach Italian Festival, helped get into the spirit of things more so than the Bud Products they were selling next door to it.
Wasn’t sure what to expect from an Italian beer, but it seemed to not have a bad taste, nothing to get excited over.  Has the consistency somewhere between a full bodied beer and a light beer.
I wasn’t very impressed but I didn’t expect much from an Italian made beer.
Just get a Miller lite, it isn’t that much of a difference.  Not bad but for an imported European beer I expected something better.  13th beer I had that day.  Go Oktoberfest!
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.
Has a light to clear yellow color. Smell has a bit of a bite to it somewhat raw. Tasted a bit skunky at first but then opened up a little and had some taste. Lacks much body. Pretty generic over all.

12 oz bottle Byblos in Center City Philadelphia-Clear golden coloring, with a very very thin/slim taste.  Its supposed to be the number 1 beer in italy, but the taste of malts/hops is nearly non-existent. It finishes crisp and light if you like that.  It tastes like a really bad rolling rock honestly, so if you like this beer its for you. Me personally, I think it was overpriced at $6 for the beer, as i’m guessing the 6 pack for the import should be around $5 at most.
Single bottle at European Street.  This beer was clear golden with a bit of skunk.  Taste is slightly hoppy but really skunked and very thin.  Bleah, this sucked.

Pale yellow with a white head. Smells grainy with a hint of spicy hops, but not much going on there. Flavor is pretty predictable - grainy, small hints of spice and that’s pretty much it. Not very exciting, pretty decent I suppose for a pale lager.

Very pale yellow wiith minimal white head.  Smells slightly skunky and a bit salty.  Flavor is watery; what’s there is skunk and salt.  Thin as water and finishes somewhat dry. Move along, nothing to see here.

My dad likes this stuff and sent me home with one. Pours a typical pale golden with a white head, average carbonation. Typical german pale lager aroma, but with out the skunk. Flavor is moderately sweet with notes of sweet white bread, leafy and herbal hops, and toasty pale malts. Finish is clean with perhaps a tiny hint of smoke (?) and some dryness. Weird. Better than Heineken or Becks.
poured a nice golden color with a nice head. smells like st. pauli girl but not much of anything else.  thin and easy on the palate and i’ve decided that if you were to mix st pauli girl and sapporo.

Sampled based on draft in a glass in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The beer had a full gold color with a big, foamy white head.  The aroma was not particularly strong, mostly hops, maybe some straw/grain notes.  Flavor was only lightly sweet, and more sour than bitter in character.  It was not particularly lively on the palate, and had a somewhat dry effect.

Poured golden in color under a thin but persistent head. Not much in the nose to speak of. Taste was malty, balanced by desent hop bitterness. Who would have though the italians could make a lager that didn’t suck
Pours a light golden color with a white head.  Aroma is of grass, hay, and malts.  Flavor is the same with minimal hop character.  Don’t really care for this beer at all.
A little bit of head. A clear golden, straw color. With hint of citrus. The taste is hoppy, a hint of malt, citrus with smooth mouth feel and a bitter finish

Draft in a mug on 06-02-07. This is the original Italian lager? Man...Italians need to learn how to make beer and badly. Clear gold and a small white head. No real aroma, so it at least can’t be offensive. Malt and grass to taste and finishing with malt and corn. Watery with ok carbonation. Drinkable because it was a hot day and I needed something badly.
Bottle. Very good Italian beer. Best beer I tried in Italy. Smooth going down with little carbonation. very pale beer.

Poured a very pale gold with a pillowy white head. Hardly any carbonation can be seen in the glass. Usual bready malt euro-lager aroma, which follows through on tasting. Weak bitterness and, thankfully, only a mild sweetness too. A bit like flavour soda water, but I guess that’s a common theme with a lot of pale lagers. Mostly inoffensive, and somewhat drinkable, but a rather unsatisfying drink

Bottle. Bland light-yellow appearance is a beacon to proceed with caution. However, temerity turns to enthusiasm as the forward hop/floral and slight skunk aroma flares the nostrils. Refreshing palate and good hop presence makes for a nice, clean, drinkable lager. Maybe a little thin, but overall a good sipper and a fine accompaniment for barbecue fare.
Typical European pale lager, crisp, smooth and a decent amount of Malt flavor.
Bottled 33cl. It pours a very pale yellow beer. Aroma of sour apples. The taste is mainly of cereals. Underhopped. A weak finish follows. Bland, watery and rather bad.

Another typical pale lager, though one with an interesting malt characteristic and somewhat smooth finish.  When it comes to the Italian lagers, I would rather have Moretti, but this is an OK lager as well.

Not a terrible beer to wash down some pizza with. Because I am forced to write 75 words, I will point out that it’s gold and barely has a taste except for that mildly sour note that typifies pale lagers.
350 mL bottle.  Light yellow color with white head.  Barely noticeable aroma and taste.  If it wasn’t for the malt, I would have been certain that this was yellow alcoholic soda water.

Light to medium yellowish with a good white head that lasted a bit.  Smell is honey malt and touch of bitter hop.  Very nice refreshing bitterness, followed by a nice smooth finish.  Nice, clean and easy to drink.  Good enjoyable beer, but could have been a touch more carbonated.  Still, was similar to a nice crisp pilsner.
Bottle. As in the picture a golden color with a white head and it tastes like it looks, thin.. A little bit of maltiness and a hint of hops. Short aftertaste.

Bottle. Drank in Rome Italy. Pale color with a thin white head. Aorma is week and flavor is refreshing and malty.

Cerveja clara com uma pequena espuma, sabor maltado e refrescante;
Fairly pale colour and thin, fading head. A hint of sweetness in aroma and taste. There’s just enough flavour to keep this interesting to drink as well as being smooth and refreshing.
Clear yellow with white head. Malty/hoppy - pale malt. A bit hay/grain. Sour thin mouthfeel with a dry short metallic end. This is not good!

Pours an uninspiring clear yellow, and there is not much head. Aroma is weak and malty. Flavor is malty and has some bitterness, but there is no depth - it tastes no different from a hundred other lagers that I have tried. At least it is not watery like some American macro-brews.
330ml bottle. Another dull Euro-lager. Easy drinking but nothing memorable in either flavour or aroma other than a metallic, industrial finish. A drink of last resort.
Bottle.  Smell of skunk with little head that didnt last.  This was my first and probably my last Italian beer.  If this is the number 1 beer in Italy, I understand their affinity for wine.  Heinous.
Tasted like most macro pale lagers.  Having it at NYNY Casino made it a bit better.  The sandwich was good.

On tap.  Little aroma.  Incredibly yeasty, a week malt flavour, and sweet but not unpleasantly so.  There is only a remote hint of bitterness.  Smooth but not crisp.  I drank 2/3rds of the beer before the unpleasant "macro-sourness" taste emerged, but it did nonetheless, although weaker than in some other European imports and certainly weaker than American macro-brews.  This was a pleasant beer to drink but I would not choose it if there were better ones available.  I like the yeasty quality and this certainly would make me choose this beer over other "pale lagers".
Bottle Not a bad beer, but nothing there to set it apart from a number of others. This is a very easy drinking lager but you can get something that tastes this good for much less.
Slightly better than many domestic pale lagers, but certainly not worth the imported cost. Highly carbonated. Reminded me of sprite.
very plae yellow colour, very typical lager hop nose, light mellow uninteresting lager.
12 oz bottle at pasta y basta for 2 bucks.  This tastes like stella or not skunky heineken.   It is over prices european macro shit.  I’ll take a high life for $1.75 over this anyday.

A pale golden yellow coloured beer with a weak white head. Light, malty nose, a touch yeasty. The taste is dry, a fizzy mouthfeel, some dry malt flavours and a hint of hop, bland. Typical of the style, nothing outstanding. (Bottle - courtesy of Mark & Marie @ The Fox & Hounds, Heacham, Norfolk).
decent body. watery in taste. like a miller .h.l without the smell and a bit more body. not bad...if it was cheap.

This reminds me of the Budweiser of Italy.  It dreams of ascending to the fair bland taste of Rollilng Rock... the best bad beer.  I could drink a lot of these, but it’s a little to rich a beer for funneling.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a clear medium gold color with a small amount of alabaster bubbles around the edges.  Aroma is of light grains, bread/dough, grass and light fruit notes.  Taste is of light grains well blended with grassy hops.  Light bodied, yet slick and smooth with ample carbonation.  Quite rich for a lager.  Ending is lightly sweet with grass and light fruit notes.
Draft.  Aroma is bready.  The flavor is like many pale lagers, but there is more bready malt than others.  Pretty dry finish.
12 oz bottle at OG. This beer had a predictable aroma, but it was not offensive like many other pale lagers. The taste was a bit dry, but good. Overall, one of the better pale lagers.
No head at all. Standard lager appearance, shallow aroma, a little dryer than average. OK for a meal or a thirstkiller.
its a pale lager. yellow color. thin body. little head. not much taste.
skunky smell. light yellow and carbonated. very basic. bland and watery. i wouldnt say its any better or any worse than others in its class. but definately nothing stands out.

Came highly recommended at my local pub. I’m beginning to think they are idiots. Peroni has absolutely no character at all. It doesn’t taste bad, but it really doesn’t have a taste. More bland even than most American beers.
Bottle, 4.7% in Rome. Sour, grainy aroma. Clear golden colour, sparkling. Big stable white head. Grainy flavour with a hint of sewer. Watery aftertaste. Prickly mouthfeel.

Pours a light clear gold with a small white head. Good carbonation. The aroma is that of a typical pale lager. Mild malts, corn, and citrus. Flavor is sort of refreshing. Crisp and mildly tart with light malts and corn. Not bad.
Bottle. Pale golden clear colour. Aroma and taste of hops, hay and citrus. A twist of light sweetness in the finish. SABMiller, maybe the new owner of Scottish Newcastle and Kronenbourg?

Can. Average white fizzy head that mostly diminished. Clear pale yellow colour. Hay, straw, cardboard, caramel. Light bodied with a thin texture. Flavour was light sweet with some notes of bitterness. Light sweet finish.
Pale golden, small white head. Malty, sugary aroma. Very weak flavor, some malt and with hoppy notes in the finish.
Clear gold, pillow white head.  Nose is lemon, slight mineralness, malty w. some dough.  Flavor is mineral & malt, some citrus.  Odd cough syrup in the finish.

Pale golden in appearance. Aroma is crisp, slightly sweet. Flavor is more hoppy than American pale lagers. Very crisp, refreshing. Tastes obviously pasteurized, but not skunky like alot of European lagers. It was very easy to drink, very crisp, and relatively pleasant.

Poured from a bottle, very pale golden color. Not very original. Nose is faint, some malt and not much else. This beer has little to no flavor, some skunkiness and sulpher if anything. With so many good beer out there, I doubt I will ever have this one again.
I like the Italian beers for some reason.  Nothing fancy, though.  Not much head, light color.  Somewhat watery, but a decent touch of flavor.
Sampled in Italy a lot on carts near the Olympic Stadium. A decent brew, better than budweiser. Not a italian masterpiece but it goes down very smooth and has a nice flavor and good kick.
Watery, little consistent cream, metallic taste, very weak aroma and coloration and none aftertaste.
Typical Italian pilsen, with a very weak aroma, taste and coloration. Nothing more to say...
not a lot of taste in the pint i had, the first time i have had it on tap. not a strong taste but easy to drink.

Clear yellow body with an average, fizzy, white head; mostly diminishing with a fair lacing.
Aroma is moderately malty and hoppy with maybe some hints of yeast.
Flavour is lightly bitter and sweet; in the finish the bitter note becomes a bit stronger.
Light-to-medium body with a watery texture; soft carbonation; light metallica feeling in the finish.
Anonymous; standard lager.
Bottle. Poured a golden color. Aroma is nothing. The taste is nasty and will never drink again.
I really, really, really, really, really, really, really, really didn’t like this.
Bottle. Golden yellow with small white head. Malt, hops and a little metallic note in the aroma. Rather watery flavor. Short finish. A thirst quencher - nothing less, nothing more.
Bottle.  Grabbed a bottle in Venice on a hot day.  It was refreshing but unremarkable.
Bottle. It’s essentially Heineken minus the obnoxious stankiness. Thin, drinkable. Unremarkable. Faced with the choice of this stuff or Miller Lite at the hospitality room. Blarrrg.
12 oz bottle.   Aroma is completely skunked, pale straw in color with high carbonation.  Taste is grainy, cooked corn(DMS) with skunky malt notes.  pretty unpleasant.
This had the flavor of major B.O. and it was just awful. The bartender recommended it, but the i much prefer the weaker flavored pale lagers that aren’t as intrusive.
We know why Italains are more known for their wines.  Tastes like a US macro w/ a hint of Heineken.
Heineken like euro-lager.  Does finish crisp.  My beverage of choice at Olive Garden.
Seems to have that "fake import" skunk to it. Pours light yellow with a small head.
i like this beer but not many places sell it, i still prefer good ol’ english beers tho

UGH UGH why did i drink this.  Poured a yellow color aroma was mostly of corn, thank goodness from a bottle and not a can then would have had corn and metal.  Flavor was corn as well.  Must be Italys Bud

the only reason i give it this rating is because of the fact that a friend let me try it, and that’s the only way it ever would have happened.  spending any money on this beer is like spending money on rolling rock.  it’s a lager.  while it has the positives of a fruity beer from the onset, the lager-ness of it rules out any chance of flavor it ever had.  the end is a below-average lager at best.  it’s alright for a lager, but that’s it.  save your money - be the dd that evening.

This beer makes me embarrassed to be Italian. Yes we "yanks" know skunky beer and this is it. It is hard to swallow and typical for a pale lager. If this was made in the US I would have rated it lower.

What the hell is a skunky beer?  Why do Yanks on this site refer to everthing as "skunky"?  I haven’t got a clue what it means!  Anyway, this lager is OK, not as bad as some of the reviews below make out, but nothing special.  Kind of reminds me of Stella, it is strongish and hoppy tasting, but a lot smoother than Stella.  (Maybe that’s what skunky means?)  Don’t get me wrong, this is not great, greasy Italians aren’t known for making beers and are better to stick to pasta, praying and crime if you ask me, but I can’t criticise this too much.

What can I say?  This is very similar to the skunky beer that is heineken, except for the fact that it tastes even more watered down.  Skunky hop aroma, watery thin mouthfeel.  Incredibly boring, skunky beer.

Had this beer multiple times, but never bothered to rate it. Pours out a medium hued yellow with a small lively head. A lot of carbonation with not much of an aroma, maybe a touch of hop. Taste isn’t bad, rather refreshing and goes down easy, just don’t let it get too warm, then it quickly goes downhill. A few noticeable hop flavors, but other than that sweet, malt. ok for this style
A good thirst quencher, I often order it whilst waiting for my pizza, drinkable, nothing special, but has abit of hops, eh...

12 oz. bottle.  Extremely pale pourwith thin, but lasting, head.  Light hoppy aroma, balanced flavor.  Not too exciting, but fairly enjoyable.  Much better than the Moretti I had afterward.  Would not seek it out, but would order again in a rstaurant setting..
Decent aroma with crisp notes and decent appearance with thin head. Flavor is decent with a slight spice to it and somewhat smooth.
It is smooth: very smooth: and it has a crisp crisp taste that has a good amount of bitterness, It is very close to heineken it taste but it is alot smoother!

Ordered this at an over-priced "fancy" Italian restaurant, figured it was a perfect place for the swill of Italy. Virtually clear, pale golden. Skunky aroma. The flavor is extremely clean. There’s an upfront skunky cheap hop flavor, with a later light corn syrup sweetness. Not the worst, but not at all good.
This was pretty fun for a lager.  Not much to celebrate, but solid with food and very drinkable otherwise.
Bottle.  Eh, not great, as it tastes the same as almost every single pale lager out there. Nothing else really to say.
Bottle.  Pretty much same taste as other Euro Lagers, though perhaps a touch more sweetness?  Also, this beer has a very odd, almost sharp after taste.  OK with Pizza, that’s about it.

I don’t understad why this beer is exported anywhere (just the same as I don’t understand why Bud is exported). Tried this beer in England on a blind buy from the supermarket. Right before I had a Budwar, then I had this and was on the verge of spitting out the beer because I was that offended by the weak, noxious taste. Aftertaste actually beats the taste itself in terms of badness. I do not wish this beer onto anyone. Really can’t do much better in Italy though.
A slightly above average beer.  Light appearance with little head.  Decent palate with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Not a bad beer, and pretty easy to drink.
Poured a golden amber with froathy white lasting head. Sweet grassy root aroma. Rich malt with bitter bite finish.

I thought this beer to be a little above average.  Bottle is nice and the appearance is nice.  Flavor is so so with the Skunky (what I cann Heineken-type flavor) flavor to it.  Don’t get me wrong.. -->Skunky means musky, not bad.

[Sampled at RGESG 2006]
Amber with a fizzy, white head.
Ok sweetness with notes of toffee. Vegetable-notes.
The aftertaste on this beer is flat out awful. The first drink was not bad but the followup made me want to stop drinking altogether, whic is really bad.

This is actually not that bad. Light aroma of a simple Lager. Clear pale golden color. It has a little more body and grain than a plis, but is pretty subdued in the hops compared to a German pils. Very drinkable if unspectacular.

Another one for the Peroni boys to celebrate. Looks like: beer. Smells like: beer. Tastes like, get this: beer. Not great beer mind you, but not shitty beer either. Middle of the road, drinkable, but boring as hell, beer. Italians make great wines and beautiful babies, but suck as beer makers.
Light golden pour with a slightly malt-ish aroma.  Taste is pretty light & grainy.  Not too bad for a macro lager, but not very good by any stretch of the imagination.
Yellow colour with a white head. Malty, grainy sweet aroma and taste with a light fruity note.

12oz bottle - pours fizzy, with little head.  Light gold color with a representative nose.  A little malt, a little hops and a watery finish in a thirst quenching sort of way.  Nothing I’ll go out of my way for.
Bottle at Bakersifelds Brews in The Village; Nose of malt with vanilla and banana hints; Gold with a small white head; grainy malt flavor.
120z Bottle.Pours clear light golden with a light head.Aromas of grain,malt and hops.Flavor of malt , grass, and hops.This is not one I will try again.
very similar to the nastro whatever.. shit I don’t think I can really tell them apart i guess this one had a tiny touch of bitter in the finish.. but still tasted like crap.

Bottle.
Clear yellow coloured with a white head.
Aroma of malts, fruits and hops with metallic notes.
Flavour of malts, fruits and hops.

This one rates pretty close to Moretti in my opinion. In fact, there are very few differences in the two. To prove, I did a side-by-side blind comparison of the two. While the Moretti did rate slightly higher, I think both fall in to the same catergory of Euro lagerland. Aroma was grains, corn and malt. Appearance is yellow, decent head, and little conditioning. Mouthfeel was slightly more alive than the Moretti, but not much. It was about to flatline any time, but I could feel a pulse now and then. Flavors were crisp, some corn, slight oxidation but overall not entirely bad. Like any lager, meant to be consumed lightning quick dare the heat creep in and..well, if that happens lock up the women and children because a warm lager is always an ugly sight.
Heavy hoppy aroma. Large creamy white head. Excellent lasing. Mostly deminishing. Clear yellow body. Moderate bitte initial flavor. Medium palate. Oily texture.
an italian lager. a golden crisp color, with a distinct sharp aftertaste and a hoppy light touch. had this with fish and chips.
Golden lager with minimal white head that is gone in an instant.  Typical taste of grain, malt, and hops.  Pretty under average brew.
Bottle at Osbournes, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, UK.  Really pale Ale.  Floral taste.  Refreshing when hot but not really tasty !

Pours to a pale yellow color, with thin white heaed that dissipates quickly, and leaves little lacing. The aroma is mostly floral, and the flavor is predominantlyt floral hops. The palate is average and smooth. This is an okay beer, and might be even better if I were having it with an Italian meal instead of just taste-testing by itself.

Bottled, pasteurised, 330ml. Golden, carbonated beer. Heavily carbonated beer with a corn, sour malt background and a touch of cardboard. My suggestion is to serve almost freezing and drink very fast, not a great beer but then, I didn’t expect it to be so.

Pan e Vino Osteria (San Diego), Seemed like a good choice over Bud and Coors light. It sucks that good food restaraunts have a huge wine list and just 5 beers (bottled!!). I say great food goes better with great beer than wine. Well it was a very nice amber red with a smal head... looked nice and smelled of malts and honey. Tasted ok at the begining a tad sweet, lots of malts, honey, but also metalic and asparagus.
Couldnt finish it though, it got to sweet and cloying at the end, warmed up horribly. Better to have ice cold and not savor it too much.

A friend brought me a bottle of this from Italy.  It pours golden yellow with the aroma of grain and malt.  Taste is malty and light.  Easy palate.  Really watery.  Finishes light and malty.  Better than most american swill.  Beats the taste if Miller Lite...not by much, but it beats it.
Bottle: Aroma with light fruity, estery notes. Flavor is unbalanced with a light, unpleasant acid touch. Bitterness and watery. Dry, light bitter finish. Unbalanced, thin, boring.

bottle.  Golden with lots of carbonation and a small head.  Aromas are grain, lightly fruity with metal.  Flavours are grain with hints of strawberry.  Dry, sweet biscuit malts follow with metallic notes on the finish.  Lots of carbonation.  Pretty poor.

Bottle. Pours a light golden amber with a satisfactory head. Nose is alightly more hoppy than other lagers, with a faint trace of malt and yeast. Taste is less like most other lagers I’ve tried. Slightly more hoppy than malty, which is a good thing. Carbonation is sufficiently satisfying. Probably one of the better lagers I’ve had.
Bottle. Thin golden color with a white head. Thin body with a slight soapy and metallic feel. Thin palate.

Straight from the bottle at the airport and on the company’s dollar. And, well, it was weak. Typical pale lager, this one was a pilsner style euro import that avoided skunkiness, but was weak. Not bad in flavor, just really weak. I interpolated the appearanced based on the style and bumped it up one, giving it the benefit of the doubt. How good could it have looked? This is grass cutting beer at best.

well, i liked it more than the tyskie, but that doesn’t say much.  i think the only reason i didn’t hate this beer is because my prior experience with italian beers is so awful i was expecting it to be awful.  you’ve escaped this time peroni.  next time i will not make the same mistake.
Clear yellow color with okay head. Ordinay and watery with a fanit hint of malt.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is pale yellow. Mediocre pale lager. Bitter aftertaste.
Bottle. Pale yellow colour with a fair moslty lasting white head. not much aroma, nor much taste. Boring.
Bottle 0,66L. Ordinary pale alger. Nice mostly lasting head. Week to no aroma. Just  a little bitter finish. Soft carbonated.
Nothing to wild or special about this brew, but doesnt mean its bad. The skunkiness people describe I didnt get...seemed quite smooth to me!

Can you say skunks ass.  PU!  Large soda bubble head that reduces quickly.  After the stink dissipates we are left with a lovely ginger ale and carbon dioxide aroma.  Bit of bland malt and hops.  Color is a pale gold.  Flavor is not as bad as the aroma.  Nothing really offensive.  Little bit of corn, malts and hops.  Goes down very easily.  Definately a gulping brew.  Clean finish.  Can hardly tell that you just had a beer.  Gotta love the quality control "Alcohol by volume over 4%, not more than 6%".  Boy, those italians are pushing the envelope.
Bottle 07-04-06 Pizza Express Oxford. Very pale yellow, not much of an aroma, refreshing and not too bad at all.
Bottle.  Pale yellow and fizzy.  Slightly sour and citric all followed by a stale aftertaste.  Bland and generic, nothing else.

Easily one of my fave lagers in the Euro-skunky tradition, but less skunky  than its competitors in that market. If it wasn’t so ridiculously expensive it would be a weekend staple. Clean and crisp in the mouth, with a good but not overpowering flavor. Bottle. Being in an authentic Italian restaurant perhaps enhances its stature. Good beer for discussing life with a neighbor, not for watching football..

Clear yellow, little head. Skunky malt aroma with some spicy hops and sweetness. Very crisp with low malt and tiny hop flavor. Finishes with good bitterness and low sweetness. The most appealing thing about this beer is the body which is surprisingly full without the beer being too sweet.

Had it from the bottle at the Olive Garden (hey, it was either that or Coors, Miller, Michelob or Budweiser).  Not much in the smell department.  Golden body with a rather surprisingly thick head from the bottle.  Taste was a little stronger than macro Americans like the afformentioned alternatives.  Inoffensive, goes well with food like one of the previous reviewers said.  Not something I’d have on a regular basis, but definitely worth having again if I find myself at a restaurant with little or no alternative.

Canned. Light yellow in colour, Minor white head. A hoppy bitter aroma, not all that pleasant, hints of metal as well, sour. The Flavour is sweet and hoppy. It doesn’t work for me. Thanks "Dorqui" for the beer.
Canned. Yellowish golden colour, mediumsized white head. Hoppy dishwater, with metallic and spicy hints, both to the flavour and aroma. Not pleasant at all, and I would rather drink water...
I can see why this is the #1 beer in a wine country. It will be pretty boring and unoffensive, but was very typical of a pale lager.
Nice, light refreshing lager to quench your thirst.  Doesn’t offer much of anything else, especially flavor.  Better than its American counterparts, not that thats saying much.
Bottle, goldeny color, white head, very weak aroma. metallic taste at the finish. an average beer.
Bottle.  Golden yellow with foamy white head.  Not much aroma.  Pretty drinkable lager (either that or I was just tired and needed a beer).
Goes great with food.  Smells interesting, tastes great for a pale.  Beats the pants off of big American pales.
I didn’t find this very different from the Nastro Azurro. A little darker in colour maybe, but still no standout features.
Supremely boring. Lifeless yellow fizz, very dull, although it seems like it may try a little bit to be tasty. Just a little. But it doesn’t succeed. At all.
Pours a nice golden yellow.  Aromas of malts, hops.  Crisp hop bitterness and dry finish.

Pal straw yellow with a slight white head, this brew had a slight lemony grainy aroma. Light tight carbonation. Balanced hop character slightly rises in finish. Dry slight tart finish. Not very good, but better than most American macro swill.

Pours a pale pale pale yellow with no lasting head.  Smells of a skunk’s ripe gland.  Some fruity notes in the flavor were this beer’s only redeeming quality.  Way too much freaking carbonation on the palate.  It’s almost as if this beer is aspiring to be a light beer.  Hmm...

This time I was lucky as to have a Peroni that didn’t smell astoundingly like sausage.  I was still disappointed though for I was still greeted with the standard aroma and taste of yet another pale lager.  Too light and too average.  If you want a pale lager, go elsewhere for 4.50 a bottle at a restaurant is far to high for this example.

From a green bottle, poured this into a Pilsner glass.  Crystal clear light straw color with an initially sizable white head.  Very visible carbonation.  Surprisingly strong aroma; mostly bready with a slight suggestion of hops.  Light and subtle taste of grain--and what’s this, white wine?  Yes, a slight vinuous quality is detectable.  Also a touch of lemon rind.  Light hops arrive for the finish, which is a tad bitter.  Effervescent.  This brew went well with my meal of pesto pasta.

YIKES! Super fizzy carbonation, golden color, fast diminishing super small head. Those are the only Super-Attributes I can give. Sweet honey and artifical lemon grase nose. Soapy taste, sweet with an unpleasant bitter finish.

Bottle. Golden colour with a slim white head. Hardly any aroma, weak something or other. Not too much taste either, a suggestion of hops and malt, a hint of bitterness. Light bodied, moderate carbonation. Another of the "good with food" brigade, although it is one of the better of that ilk..
For being a lager, it was a good beer for me. Although I had a little time to drink it. The hops were very notable there and the aroma was a little strong but nice.
Sweet veggie nose, pale gold, low scumy head. Sweet taste, sugary with no bitter. Soapy mouthfeel and watery. Not good at all.
The Budweiser of Italy. Gold color. Looks like apple cider. Very little head. Taste is smooth but with no hop bitterness. Forgettable.
Can. Golden colour with a white head. Weak grassy aroma and a grassy dry taste. Light body and a dry finish. Boring
Weak, pallid, uninspired, watery, but will successfully wash down a pizza...

The most common Italian beer. The colour is dark golden with a non-existing head. A light bitter and somehow sweet taste that Italians seem to appreciate. I have to admit if flows easily in the throat. Some aromas of grass and cereals that are hard to identify; a light body with an oily texture. Carbonation is so flat that it seems to be water.
If I had to drink beer along a salad, Peroni might be a good pick.
Basic color, with some head.  It has a fine hop taste with a lot of yeast.  It has a strong bitter aftertaste.
Bottle, Thin, watery, crisp, dry, boring. Nothing more to say...............................
Bottle. Pale gold, no nose some bitterness in mouth carbonated overly, but very bitter finish
Golden color with a large white head.  Moderate malty aroma.  Taste - some malt, even less hop bitterness.  Not a bad beer, but very plain.
This is from Italy, so, extra points. This poured pale, had a pale taste, was a bit watery , and really is not that good.
A decent alternative to american swill.  A light colored and flavored beer.

It’s flavor is smooth, crisp, & consistant. But overall it’s a little to "light" for my tastes. Not much of an after-taste, and scant on hops. This does not taste like an average European lager. Green bottle, but absolutely no skunk. If it were less expensive I’d say it was great for a "lawn mowing brew". Otherwise I say it’s an interesting diversion to try at a restaurant once in a while.
A nice, crisp lager from a country not known for beer.  Balanced hops and malt with a subdued finish.  Great session beer.
Finally had Peroni, it lived up to the expectation, which wasn’t that high, but I liked it, a typical pale lager, first Italian beer that I have had
Bottle. Unfortunately a green bottle. More unfortunately a skunked green bottle. Pale yellow with no head to speak of. Aroma and taste are the same: skunk, stale grass and corn. No thanks.
Advertised as "Italy’s Number 1 Beer". Which is about the same as being England’s Number 1 Dentist.

12 oz bottle. No surprise to see this in the 12th percentile.  It has an unappealing aroma and taste, and actually a bit more body than I was expecting.  It was hard to get beyond the pee color with a hint of brown (not amber) mixed in.  It did have a decent head, but it dissipated. If this is truly "#1 in Italy," I pity my Italian friends.
Standard euro-skunk lager. Pale yellow with no head. Aroma is skunky, grassy hops. With all skunk flavor. Can check Italy off the countries list though!

Poured similar to any other pale lager with a slim white head and golden color.  Beer was well-balanced and rather refreshing for the style.  There was also a little nostalgia factor.. because I remember having a few of these in Rome at the source.
Typical pale lager. If you’ve had one, you’ve had them all. Save some money and get a domestic one.

It’s a wonderful history.  Three 13th century Benedictine monks were forced from their monastery in Tuscany to establish a colony in northern Europe after a squabble over succession and some minor theological issues had split the house.  They wandered through northern France and Belgium before settling in north-western Germany, where they established a successful monastery that flourished.  Learning the regional brewing techniques, so necessary in a time of unclean water, they perfected the style, and then, forced out two centuries later by the Reformation, these exiled Benedictine colonies were reconciled and welcomed back to Italy, where they brought their beer to the traditional wine region, and particularly the Monasterie de Monteverde et Peroni, where it is still being faithfully brewed to this day.  Or, maybe this is just a cheap mass produced yellow lager with a skunky nose and mild skunky flavor that is an insult to the culture of fine gastronomy that is Italy.  You pick.
usual light skunky lager aroma.  dark yellow in color.  light and bland flavor.  very smooth with no aftertaste.
erm. not much to say, nose isa bit hoppy i suppose, mouth is thin, finish is very very slightly bitter, pretty bland, useless stuff.

well what can you say for this beer. served as part of the ’authentic’ cuisine at every american italian restaurant in the nation. crystal clear malty flavors. easy to drink but why would you. moretti is slightly superior.
Didn’t like this one. Poured very light yellow with decent head. Nothing really stands out  but the taste is very light and watery.

I had an interesting experience with this one.  A friend brought it back from Italy and we didn’t have a bottle opener around.  We were outside so I decided to use the curb which worked just fine.  Unfortunately I broke part of the top of the bottle as well.  My first sip cut my mouth.  It was a decent pale lager, but it was pretty hard to really enjoy with a cut lip.
This is probably Italy’s generic beer. Sort of like the Sicilian Miller. While not a bad tasting beer nothing stands out at the palate.

Green bottle poured yellow with a good head.
Aroma is of corn and soap.
Flavor is malt and corn with a metalic finish.
Bottle-Rudy’s Pizza, NYC-Definitely not the worst beer I’ve had. my guess is that, as long as it’s fresh, it’s quite refreshing. Nothing stands out, just a standard Pale Lager.
not bad kinda skunked like a heineken. way to overpriced for a six pack. not that bad going down. kinda like the italian budweiser, that tastes like a heineken
gold, really sweet, no head... i just bought it for italian fest at my friends.. too damn sweet.. im not really a fan

(Bottle 33 cl) As with most Italian lagers a darker malt is used, making this not pale at all. Rather it’s a fully golden almost amber coloured beer. Small, creamy head and highly carbonated. Very well-balanced between malt-sweetness and hops. An ordinary, commercial Lager but a decent one as such. 180305
Canned: Golden coloured. Clear. White medium sized head. Hay and sweetness in the aroma. Flavour of malt and metal. Is light sweet in the end. Not much power on aroma nor flavour.

Had this at an Italian restaurant last night; it was surprisingly tasty.  Looks like a typical pale lager.  Aroma of fresh, grassy hops with a touch of sweetness.  Taste is mostly hoppy, herbal and grassy, and a bit spicy.  Finishes dry and carbonated.  Refreshing.

Vas ist das "premium bier"? Zis ist anuzzer poor attempt at real bier. Ze flavor vas not bat but ze aroma stinktet into ze highest heaven. 
Earlier Rating: 2/28/2005 Total Score: 2
I had this at The Olive Garden and surprisingly, it was fresh but that didn’t really make it good. Just another run of the mill lager except it had an aroma of dried saliva! Yuck! I held my breath as I drank it and let the slight malt flavor finish off the beer.

Pale clear yellow, quickly fading thin white head. Dry ricey aroma with light hop notes. Very watery taste, with light hop bitterness and a slight fruity sweet balance. It has interesting flavor for a pale lager, however that doesn’t make it good.
LIte golden color with white head.  Nothing really special.  Very clean finish, not a lot going on.  Not my style of beer.
Basic lager style beer. Golden color, little nose and no special characteristics. Great on a hot day when you want to quench your thirst...or have with some nachos.

The VB of Italy?  Certaintly priced that way at e0.95.....

Ultra clear pale gold with a boring nose, very largerish, slightly stale feel.  Reminds me of Melbourne Bitter. Non descript palate, no malt character to speak of but does have a faintly bitter and somewhat zesty finish. Pass.

This beer might be alittle bit better thank your average american lager but this italian brew still has a long way to go.  Kind of the Bud of Italy the flavors of slight hops and barley combine to give the drinker a less than mediocore experience.

A good simple lager to eat with pizza or maybe burgers.  When you look at it, it is deceptively clear but the flavor is better than I expected after seeing it.  This is the sort of lager that would probably have a great popular appeal, but not something so much for serious connoissieurs.

A clear yellow pour with white fluffy head and some lacing.  The flavor reminds me of fruit or the aftertaste of a wine.  Works well with an Italian meal, not anything spectacular, but certainly drinkable.

Have you thought about trying the wine instead? Then do. This is a staple of the Roman piazza and I have imbibed my fair share of this ubiquitous, drinkable (if nothing else)  lager in Rome but don’t tell my friends. It is not without character though. How about dried grass with a small hint of floral aroma. There is almost no skunk when drank from the brown bottles of Italy rather than the green bottles that we Yankees get.

Light yellow. No real head.
Smells haylike, little flowery and just a tiny bit skunky.
Tastes lightly hopped, slightly sweet, and fresh.
Very crisp, finishes just a bit dry.
I say it’s closest counterpart would be Heineken. Though it beats out Heineken in just about every category. 
Overall, it’s a good lager. Moderately priced - $4.95 a sixpack at the El Ranchero Market. Tastes good and is very drinkable.

Aroma is totally skunk. Taste is mostly skunk but a bit of the malt shows through as well. Peroni may be better in Italy but I’m not going to make a special trip. I swear this is the LAST green bottled foreign beer I will ever buy!

2004 bottle @ Cafe Tremonte in Woburn, MA.  Well I wanted a beer with dinner on Friday night and as the only other options were bud, bud lite and amstel lite, I chose this (the lesser of four evils?), so I may as well rate it.  I really like Silktork’s review of this and reading it now, it is funny that he mentions how pasteurisation dosent seem to have as much of an effect on lagers as ales.  I found myself babbling about this to my girlfriend while I was drinking it, something to the tune of, "this really isnt that bad for a pasteurised, filtered beer."  And it isnt.  Nothing great, but it has a good sparkle from the fake carbonation, which, when factoring in the small bite of hops makes this very refreshing.  Served in a kolsch glass, I drank this thing in about a minute.  Pale yellowish-green color, small white head.  Aroma of light apples and grass.  Relative to most other beers in the style, it’s quite good.

While the reviews on here don’t make this beer sound very good nothing could be farther from the truth. This beer has a wonderful smell and unique taste. It is ricey but also grassy with a wonderful floral hop. I really like this beer.

Thin, ricey, headless, watery, slight skunk, but overall harmless.  Not good, but it won’t kill you.
Sampled on tap in Rome, but bottled is not any better.
Gold Coloring.  Carbonated....and Lawn Mower Written All Over It.  Smooth and Drinkable but Nothing Noteable or Special.
Easy to drink and bland without being unpleasant. I obviously had this thirst-quencher at the wrong time of year.

If you’re having a pizza and that pizza is covered with pepperoni and sausage and onions and sprinkled with crushed red pepper and you’ve had six slices without anything to drink and you’re getting to the point where you need something to wash down that pizza,  this stuff places fourth after wine, Coke, and water.
Between the Italians it is not from despising. Body and moderated bitter, little persistent foam. In the sufficient complex.

What the hell? you guys are clueless.
Peroni red label is the best beer in the whole world!
This beer gets me pussy.

Fairly smooth with more hops earlier on in the drinking sequence.  This one tastes too much like Miller Lite for my likes.  I generally opt for Moretti - it’s slightly more bitter, and I appreciate a bit of an aftertaste when it comes to lagers.

In the bottle. Skunked to high heaven (what did you expect from a green bottle?). Rich golden color with big fluffy white head. Good retention, but no lacing. Strange. Good malt content and a very pleasant bitter flavor, but that skunky taste is too much to overcome. Maybe someday I’ll have a bottle of this that has not turned.
Big bottles in Northern Italy.  Stand up crisp clean lager; dry sharp hop finish.  Excellent in the summer heat.
I thought this beer as ok, decent flavor, slighlty bitter, malty little bit of a kick better then average if i needed to order it again I could. Surprised it did so poorly with others

bottle. poured a nice golden color with a meduim sized head. aroma light malts some sweetness. flavor malts some sweetness to it a hint of bitterness with a hint of skunk. went ok with my Italian dinner I am glad it was a speial for $2.00
Your run of the mill pale lager, however this one seems to be spiced up with the bubbly humor and dilatory history of Italy.
Bottle. Slightly skunky and bland. Absolutley nothing stands out about this beer. I like skunky beers, and this one wasn’t skunky enough. It wasn’t bitter, malty, or anything. Blah.
Looks like an american pale... tastes SLIGHTLY better than an american pale lage. I was able to finish the glass, so I guess it deserves credit for that much.
Not a bad beer, not that great either.  Nicely golden color.  What I thought beer was before I started drinking beer.
Golden coloured with a disappering head. Somewhat malty aroma. Sweet and malty flavour. Drinkable, but that’s about it.
Okay but nothing special stood out.  Pours a thick white head and had with little to none aroma.  Flavor is kind of bland at times but not too bad.  Overall there just wasn’t anything to it.

I’m sorry for not getting this garbage out of the way years ago.  After I rated Doggie Claws I saw someone else had rated this.  Boy did it bring back some awful memories.  This crap sucks....and that’s putting it nicely.  There’s a local Italian restaurant that promotes this crap.  The server looked totally insulted when I told her how much they were ripping off folks by charging $4.00/bottle.....can you believe that?  I bet if Bush or Kerry would stand up for craft beer they’d carry the election.  Geez....$4....something stinks bad there.  Anyway, it’s that bad, from start to finish.  It’s like that guy on the lable is just snickering at you.  It don’t taste like a fart like Corona, but it’s darn close.  Do yourself a favor and avoid this garbage.  BTW, I’m writing this based on an experience from some time ago.  I’d never try this again, not even on a bet.

At least it doesn’t give you the shits like drinking the water in Italy does.  Its available just about everywhere there, and if you don’t want the wine this is about the only choice.  Not bad but not good either.   House wine is the better choice. 1.2  .. .. rerate: 04 Sep 2009 ..  12oz bottle at Aaron’s Pizza in Orange Park, FL.   Had a cold one straight from the bottle with a large mushroom and black olive pizza.  My wife had a glass of wine so I had the opportunity to compare the beer to a medium-low quality California Cabernet Sauvignon.  The beer was a better match to the pizza.   Flavor was better than I remember from years ago, with sweet pale malts and a mild hop bitterness, better tasting than the typical American macro lager.   It hit the spot pretty well, and I would have had a second had I not been driving. 2.2

Bitter taste. Average. Nothing to get your attention. Boring really. Light enough to enjoy with a heavy dinner, but that’s pushing it. You would think the place that gave birth to Versace, Prada, and Dolce&Gabbana would have created a much more elaborate beer.

Not hard to find the skunky one.  I do not know if I would go so far as to call it the Italian Rolling Rock.  A little watery and sweet.  Pretty well balanced.  Not bad but sometimes when in the Italian district and eating Italian food, besides wine, an Italian beer sounds nice and this is all that is usually offered.

Comparable to Birra Moretti but has less malt and is a little more watery. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is non-existent - a slight hint of malt. Taste is moderatly sweet with some caramel. Mouthfeel is weak and watery. Not good but not necessarily offensive either.

As my friend beaconstreet put it in his rating, I did at first compare this to an Italian version of Rolling Rock.  Which it sort of is, though I might lean more towards Miller High Life now.  I probably wouldn’t buy this.

Tastes a bit common, but has a slight edge of distinction.  Kind of bitter at some sips?  Oh yeah, definitely a sipping beer.  Jine says this is like an Italian Rolling Rock, I think it might be like an Italian Heineken, but a stroke better.  It’s okay, and looks classy. Bubbly. Appropriate for a banquet probably.

This is much like most of the macro pale lagers on the market... except that one has to pay more because it’s imported from Italy.  Not a bad drink, but it offers little special for its cost.  Mild malt aroma, mild body, mild taste.
Don’t remember when I drank this beer, but I found the lable in my wallet with the ratings and info on the back.  Not a very good beer, but drinkable.

This was very pleasant beer with an Italian disk of sausage.  Not outstanding but very drinkable.  The head was small but stayed with beverage.  The color was gold and the aroma had hints of hops.  Christmas beer 2013.  Medium body with soft carbonation. Grassy taste on the finish

Had this on 9-5-04 at Tuscany Ristorante in Newport News, VA. Bottled. Pours an efferevescent straw colored blond. Medium white head. It settles quickly with only some foam around the edges of the glass. Nose is mildly malted and slightly grassy. Pleasant enough and not skunky - obviously a fresh bottle. Taste is about where I expected it to be. Minimal malt with some cereal and grassy notes. Hint of cardboard. Palate is light but moderately carbonated. Finish is more cereal and some sweetness. Not too bad! Went well with dinner also!
Not too bad a stab at the easy drinking lager category.  A little weak, but very drinkable.

Oh my god... my friend slides my the bottle in disgust.  "How bad could it be?" I wonder.  As I tip the bottle towards my nose and mouth, a skunk lifts its tail and blasts me in the face with its stank.  I’m sure it was a light struck bottle, but I couldn’t even pick up on anything else underneath it.  No points.
nothing very exciting, i might be a little bored of serving it all day long at work, i would still perfer moretti

Not dissimilar to the Birra Moretti I had earlier: a sweet pale lager with a bitter aftertaste. However, I think the craftsmanship is a bit below the Moretti. The beer poured a clear gold. The aroma was of sweet malt, less sour than the Moretti. The head was decent sized but quickly faded into a yeasty film. The flavor was sweet and malty as well, but the aftertaste was quite bitter and bordering on metallic/medicinal. Not a great beer.

Bottled (BB 12/2004)

Dark honey yellow, small white head. Aroma is sweetish malts, a bit unclean. Bitterish palate, lacking malt volume and flavor has hints of corn. One-dimensional and boring.

(Bottled) Golden color with small head. Fruity, reasonably malty, sweet aroma with pear and berry notes. Somewhat malty, fruity flavor with low bitterness and no finish. Light to medium-bodied, carbonated palate. Interesting aroma, but dull flavor and quite light and carbonated body.

This is another of the total brain explosions where I have had this so often but never rated it. Here we have what is a typical euro lager with at least a bit of character. The presentation is as generic euro as can be, as is the nose and flavour. This is a good beer when fresh and the need for a cold crisp beer arises. At the moment in wet and cold Sydney this one does not beckon at all.
Pours gold, smells light but nice, has flavor of hops but is mild.  Overall not bad at all for a session pale lager.
I drink this often in when i was in italy and doesn’t know much abbouıt beer culture.But it was golden colour.Quite nice aroma.But bitterness after taste.Not so deep.Normal for lagers I guess.

Yellow with a medium sized white head
that quickly dissipated. Faint malt aroma.
Thin, sweet lager with a bit of skunkiness. Not sure if this was intended or from the green bottle. Very
little hop presence.
Golden Lager + Import = Boredom. This beer is very run-of-the-mill, average, plain, and boring. There’s nothing about this beer that yu haven’t had if you’ve had Heineken.

Unfortunately, I have nothing clever to say, so I am pretty much going to copy my rating for Moretti...Mr. Peroni, I would like you to meet my friend Mr. Moretti...I think you two have a lot in common...maybe they shoulda calleda thisa beera Heinekena (me speaking with a cheesy Italian accent)

Pretty much reminded me of any other run of the mill European brew.  Smooth sweet taste with a slightly bitter aftertaste.  Better than American macros, but stil has a watery feel to it.  It was, however, perfect for the context in which it was drank.  I had it during a dinner with my girlfriend on a hot humid day at an italian restaurant where we were eating outside.  I had a spicy pasta which it helped cool.  Overall, I enjoyed the beer as much for the context as for the taste.

The easiest description is bitter-sweet although the sweet taste hits you first and then the slightly bitter after taste.  I’m not a fan of this sweet taste, but I could still drink it and enjoy it.  And it’s a lot more pricey than most beers.

Ok upon further inspection this beer certaintly shouldn't be drank ice-cold.  Take it out of the fridge and let it cool down a bit, and perhaps you will find a tasty treat.

Hmm...I remember thinking, "Ick!" when I tried this beer on the streets of Rome.  Even very chilled I didn’t like it.  Thin and watery with a soured hoppy flavor, it just didn’t agree with me like St. Josef’s or Strongbow.  I actually remember my friends pouring some of this stuff out.  It’s OK...but then, it’s not that good.  Reminds me of a lesser Spaten Premium Lager.  It was cool to get it from a street vendor though.  Extra points there.
A decent tasting beer.  Medium bodied with not too much after taste.  A little sweet and satisfying.  Had this on my 21st birthday.
bottle. Clear yellow color with smallish head. Light malty aroma with a bit of skunkiness. Nice with Italian food if you’re having only one.

Lightish lager with a yeast aroma and a sweetish dry flavour.  Overall an average beer but good for an Italian effort.
Earlier Rating: 9/1/2003 Total Score: 2.8
Golden lager with a very bland airy aroma, and a malty/slightly dry flavour.  A refreshing summer brew.
This is a gross beer.  Highly malted and sweet... you don’t make a beer "red" by adding sugar and malt, right?  Tell these guys.  Gross.

I used to work in an Italian Resturant and people would order this all the time. NO! Get a red wine! Well anyway this a golden color with little head. It has a crisp grassy flavor to it. This junk has an insane price tag. Its your standard lager really.
This beer has a golden body - hue apperance and a white scum collar. I have drunk the beer from the tap and it had a no carbonic acid. The initial flavor tast was sweet/bitter.
osvjezavajuce pivo sa malo alkohola, za cjelodnevno uzivanje u toplim danima.

Mild malt aroma with matching flavor.   While it does have the unfortunate distinction of sharing its name with a certain disease that only affects men it is a refreshing beer to enjoy on an Italian beach.
Light malty aroma with a hint of citrus. Pale golden, white head, fair lace. Light sweet, malty, light bitter, light herbal, medium body. Not a bad pils compared to all the other Italian pilseners.

Gold with a white head and spotty lacing. Lively carbonation. From 3 feet away, I can smell the skunk of the lightstricken pilsner malts. Other than that there is some light hops. The flavor isn’t half bad. Some musky pils malts and a touch of sweetness. Slightly bitter hops. Palate is sharp, slightly acidic, the body is light and it finishes of with a bitter bite at the end.
Pours gold, with white head.  Aroma of slight malt, corn.  Tastes slightly better than American swill, with some dryness, hops, and malt in the finish.

I think I had a fresh bottle because the best before date said 05/05 on it.  It didnt taste skunky or off, and was actually quite nice and refreshing.  Granted it was quite bland with not much special about it, but it was a nice fathers day beer.  I liked this a little better than their gran reserva.

Bottled. Peroni Red, I’d have to agree with Austinpowers its just like a regular Peroni only more amber, rather then pale golden. A very no-descript larger but thoroughly enjoyed in last nights heat. 
Earlier Rating: 6/20/2003 Total Score: 2.1
Bottled. Bright and bubbly, straw coloured larger. Slight malt taste with low bitterness. Too fizzy to drink any real quantity of.
Nothing exciting about this Peroni, or any I’ve had.  Maybe the Italians should just stick to wine.
The only beer at Olive Garden that I had never tried. This stuff has the same skunky taste and smell that Heineken does. Not worth a second shot at all.

Sour corn aroma and a light head with sizzle. Pale yellow color and a sticky palate. Obviously an Italian response to american mass produced swill that floods domestic and foreign markets. Does this make Peroni "Euro-trash"? Regardless, the taste is acrid and peppery. Patheticly sold as a charming Italian beer to unsuspecting, unaware Olive Garden patrons across the U.S..

Smells like corn, tastes like corn.  The body poured a clear golden/straw color with a thin off-white head.  The flavor was dominated by corn and plenty of artificial sweet flavor.  Vegetabley and not very pleasant.  Hops leave a grassy mouthfeel.  Too sweet and slightly offensive for a cheap lager.
why is it that  "the number one beer in (insert country here)" tastes exactly like budweiser?

i was at olive garden and i figured what the hell.  it was the only beer i hadn’t tried on the menu.  so, this is the italian version of budweiser.  pale yellow.  tastes like a bud.  nothing much else to say
Golden yellow body. A jumpy felling because of the quantity of carbon dioxide. An easy beer to drink. Doesn«t make much noise.
Bottled.  My first "pale lager" under the new categorization system, and boy does this one fit the bill.  It’s Italian Budweiser, period.  There’s nothing more I can really say about it.
A light lager with a golden color and weak aroma. Not particularly tasty, but I was at least happy that it was not skunky.
A nice golden appearance and small white head. A light skunky aroma. Nothing really special, just something to drink. Typical Italian beer.

Bottle. Light golden beer with virtually no head. Very faint aroma, a tiny bit of skunk. Tastes like a watered down Heineken. Grassy, dry finish. Nothing intersting or offensive, just an easy to drink blah beer. Good with my scallop scampi. When a beer says it is a country's number one beer, you can bet it will be pretty boring and unoffensive to the masses.

Pours golden, but with no head to speak of.  Very smooth and refreshing.  Goes well with an italian dish with red sauce and meat like suasage, pepperoni or meatballs.  You don't need a lot of flavor in this beer if you drink it in the appropriate setting.  Best served cold, but not ice cold.

A basic pale lager with nothing to distinguish it from the multitude of international pale lagers. +++ Sampled from a 12 oz green bottle this beer pours a light golden color with a large white head. There is a slight sour, grassy aroma. The texture is smooth but the brew is relatively flavorless. Very little body. No skunkyness, or any offending flavors, but not really any good flavors either. There really is not much to this beer.
Bottled at a Don Giovanni's pizza place in Philly. Smelled and tasted like a Heiniken (sp). Skunky. The death date was 11/04 so this was far from being bad. This wasn't good.

The aroma and flavour for this beer are definitely macro-beerish. You can tell it's mass produced. The palate is lacking and somewhat stale. Its aroma smells a little like copper to me. My overall impression was not so very favourable.
Macro!! Of course. You pretty much know that the hops and malt will be weak. Slightly skunly and pours with a small white head.
Not a big fan of this one.  Needs a bit more carbonation and a bit more taste.  I think it travels poorly because more often than not I get it when it smells terrible.
Smelled awful. Pours a blond color with a decent head. Can taste the hops. Better than Yuengling.
Mid-yellow clear colour with quickly dissipating head. Very faint hops and carbonic acid mineral water aromas. Very light to weak palate and refreshing dry finish. Not bad for an Italian macrobrew.
Italy in the beer business?  Oddly enough, but true.  Typical lager, not much to say.
poured a pale yellow.Lots of carbonation with a ver small head.Had a little skunky aroma to it.Slight hop flavor,with a bitter follow-up.A ok beer
Very sweet fizzy yellow beer, cloyingly so, with little hops and little to make it better than Genny Light.  Had it with some fried calamari at mario's via abruzzi.
Blond color. Sweet corn aroma. Some sweetness, corn, poor hop. Poor table beer.

Bottle at the Italian Courtyard restaurant in Cocoa Beach. This beer had a small sized white head that contained fine-small sized bubbles that were long lasting. The body was carbonated and transparent with a yellow hue. The nose was malty and some hop notes were detected. The flavor was lightly malty with a smooth mouthfeel. This was a medium bodied beer with a fair amount of lacing on the sides of my glass.

TheDM and Hotstuff vacation brew 57.  This bottle labelled best before 12/04 was smpled with our pizza dinner at a most excellent restaurant called the Italian Courtyard in Cocoa Beach Florida.  It poured a medium head of finely sized white colored long lasting bubbles that left behins a transparent light yellow orange colored carbonated body.  The aroma was a smooth mild malt hop one and the mouthfeel was smooth and tingly.  The flavor was a simple mild malt hop one, but it went oh so well with our pizza that I found myself thinking it was the perfect brew at the perfect time.

This beer is consistently average.  Have had in Italy and in the U.S. and it tastes exactly the same whether on tap or from bottle.  Inital flavor is a bit skunky, but leaves quickly and is certainly drinkable.  I always grab one at U.S. Italian restaurants because it makes me think of all those late suppers in Italia... Viva la birra!
A malty lager with a bit of skunk aroma that seems typical of the green-bottled european style. Drinkable, ok with food but overall just another lager.

A very average lager.  A bit of a skunky aroma.  Minimal head.  Typical golden pilsner color.  Weak palate but pretty filling and goes okay with Pizza, Antipasto, Italian Food, etc.  Malty.  A bit metallic on the finish.  I think I like this better than the similar Moretti, but with either, nothing really great happening!

Bought in the green 12 oz bottle..like the label.
Just an average lager in appearance pale golden small white head..some lacing after head goes.
NOt much of an aroma at all..some faint grassiness..sweet.
The taste is pretty Ok for a Euro-lager..not as sweet as some..small hop bite .
Pretty average on the tongue..maybe a but over carbonated..semi-dry finish.
Drinkable but forgettable.
Bottle: Was expecting skunk-juice with the green bottle. Much to my surprise it was fresh tasting. Clean malty with a crisp dry finish. It didn't suck.

Nov, 2003 Bottle. Pastuerised. The pastuerising process doesn’t appear to have such a dramatic effect on lager as it does on ale. And the quick squirt of fizz feels appropriate. These bog standard global lagers are not so much about flavour as about being thirst quenching. This one does the job quite nicely - it doesn’t taste bad, and it washes down a quick lunch. Great beer it aint. [2.0]

Jan, 2007 Bottle from BeersOfEurope. A clean, sweet lager with a mild salty bitterness in the finish. OK. [2.2]

Light toast malt aroma with a touch of hops in the end. Light golden color with a little lacing and small head. Flavor is lightly sweet with a nice toasty but semi-bitter finish. This isn't a bad lager, it's just a bland internationally brewed one.
Easy drinking beer, and thats about all it has going for it. Thin and bland.
Beer -light colour with little head, a tad skunky, earthy, grassy.  Average. cheers
Yeah, not quite right. Tastes very grassy and grainy. Very rich, sweet and peculiar. Not a great tasting beer for mine.
Bottle: dull, stale with light yellow color and average taste. Not much of a Lager.
Light gold color with little head. Faint skunkiness. Definitely not one I would search out!

Light gold lager/pilsner color. Nasty green bottle leads once again to a skunked lager. Funny that this keeps on happening. I like how it says it has a well-balanced hop taste. Not really. A little tangy and better than Birra Moretti. Peroni would be so much better if it lost the bottle. The flavor is there but the skunked smell throws it out of balance.

Italian lager, doesnt really roll of the tongue does it?  I gave it a shot though. Pulled out the frozen mug and went to work.  I was surprised by its easy taste.  It was a bit skunky, but I didn't mind, I was just happy that I actually enjoyed drinking it.  Italy you haven't disappointed us all.

I am actually suprised that this is rated so low. Has a very nice cascade, medium sized head with a clearer yellow colour. Floral head, slightly skunky but not overbearing. The taste was slightly bitter but mostly hoppy. Overall, quite nice and easily drinkable.
(Bottle)  Poured a light yellow with very little head.  This beer was refreshing and had floral accents.
